title: Riemann's paradox: pi = infinity minus infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the Riemann rearrangement theorem?

options.label: A
options.text: A theorem that states that a convergent series can be rearranged to have any sum.

options.label: B
options.text: A theorem that states that a divergent series can be rearranged to have any sum.

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that states that a series with positive terms that add up to infinity and negative terms that add up to negative infinity can be rearranged to have any sum.

options.label: D
options.text: A theorem that states that a series with positive terms that add up to a finite number and negative terms that add up to a finite number can be rearranged to have any sum.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the terms of an infinite series are rearranged?

options.label: A
options.text: The sum of the series remains the same.

options.label: B
options.text: The sum of the series changes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a convergent series and a divergent series?

options.label: A
options.text: A convergent series has a finite sum, while a divergent series has an infinite sum.

options.label: B
options.text: A convergent series has a finite sum, while a divergent series has a negative sum.

options.label: C
options.text: A convergent series has a sum that converges to a finite number, while a divergent series has a sum that diverges to infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: A convergent series has a sum that converges to a finite number, while a divergent series has a sum that converges to infinity.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when an infinite series is bracketed?

options.label: A
options.text: The sum of the series changes.

options.label: B
options.text: The sum of the series remains the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Riemann zeta function?

options.label: A
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the sum of an infinite series.

options.label: B
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the convergence of an infinite series.

options.label: C
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the sum of a finite series.

options.label: D
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the convergence of a finite series.

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered the Riemann rearrangement theorem?
What is the difference between a series that converges to a finite number and a series that diverges to infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is greater than infinity, while a series that diverges to infinity has a sum that is less than infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is equal to infinity, while a series that diverges to infinity has a sum that is less than infinity.

options.label: C
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is less than infinity, while a series that diverges to infinity has a sum that is greater than infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is equal to infinity, while a series that diverges to infinity has a sum that is equal to infinity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Riemann integral?

options.label: A
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the sum of an infinite series.

options.label: B
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the convergence of an infinite series.

options.label: C
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the sum of a finite series.

options.label: D
options.text: A function that is used to calculate the convergence of a finite series.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a series that converges to a finite number and a series that converges to infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is greater than infinity, while a series that converges to infinity has a sum that is less than infinity.

options.label: B
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is equal to infinity, while a series that converges to infinity has a sum that is less than infinity.

options.label: C
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is less than infinity, while a series that converges to infinity has a sum that is greater than infinity.

options.label: D
options.text: A series that converges to a finite number has a sum that is equal to infinity, while a series that converges to infinity has a sum that is equal to infinity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Riemann hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: A hypothesis that states that a series with positive terms that add up to infinity and negative terms that add up to negative infinity can be rearranged to have any sum.

options.label: B
options.text: A hypothesis that states that a series with positive terms that add up to a finite number and negative terms that add up to a finite number can be rearranged to have any sum.

options.label: C
options.text: A hypothesis that states that a series with positive terms that add up to infinity and negative terms that add up to negative infinity can be rearranged to have a sum that converges to a finite number.

options.label: D
options.text: A hypothesis that states that a series with positive terms that add up to infinity and negative terms that add up to negative infinity can be rearranged to have a sum that diverges to infinity.
